column1: A cataract is a clouding of the lens of the eye.
The lens of the eye is normally clear.
As a person ages, proteins in the lens begin to break down.

Factors that may speed cataract formation are: - Diabetes - Eye inflammation - Eye injury - Family history of cataracts - Long-term use of corticosteroids (taken by mouth) or certain other medicines - Radiation exposure - Smoking - Surgery for another eye problem - Too much exposure to ultraviolet light (sunlight) In many cases, the cause of cataract is unknown.
- By age 75, most people have cataracts that affect their vision.

Problems with seeing may include: - Being sensitive to glare - Cloudy, fuzzy, foggy, or filmy vision - Difficulty seeing at night or in dim light - Double vision - Loss of color intensity - Problems seeing shapes against a background or the difference between shades of colors - Seeing halos around lights - Frequent changes in eyeglass prescriptions Cataracts lead to decreased vision, even in daylight.
A standard eye exam and slit-lamp examination are used to diagnose cataracts.
